Details: The robot takes mixed laundry from a hamper, neatly folds it, and stacks it in piles according to type
Notes:
- Ubiquitous scenario
- Compact and easy to set up
Variations:
- The items in the hamper
- Introduce bulky items (jackets, etc)
- Introduce other types of items (towels, sheets)

Details: The robot takes washed dishes from a sink and places them neatly in a dish rack to dry
Variations:
- The type/number/color of each dish
- Introduce other cookware (mugs, pots, pans)

Details: The robot removes dry dishes from a dishwasher and neatly organizes them on a countertop or in a cabinet
Notes: - Requires the robot to move down in Z to get items from the dishwasher, then move back up
Variations:
- The type/number/color of each dish
- Introduce other cookware (mugs, pots, pans)

Details: The robot takes items from a bin or basket and scans the barcodes on them with a countertop barcode scanner
Notes: - Requires the robot examine each object to find the barcode
Variations:
- The items in the basket
- The type of item (groceries, cosmetics, tools, ...)

Details: The robot takes items from a mixed bin (containing multiples of each item) and sorts them into their labeled positions on a store shelf
Notes: - Requires the robot to read the label on the shelf and find the corresponding item in the bin
Variations:
- The items in the bin
- The positions of each item on the shelves
- Introducing bad items (which do not correspond to a label)

Details: The robot takes fasteners or other small industrial parts from a bin of mixed parts and sorts them into labeled compartments in a parts organizer
Notes: - Requires the item to read the labels in the organizer and find the corresponding item through visual recognition only (the parts are not labeled)
Variations:
- The items in the bin and the labels on the organizer
- The positions of each compartment on the organizer
- Introducing bad items (which do not correspond to a label)

Details: The robot places spools of electronic components into labeled positions on a shelf
Notes: - Requires the robot to read the labels on each spool and match them with the labels on the shelf (the spools all look identical)
Variations:
- The composition of the spools
- The positions of each component type on the shelves
- Damaged labels on spools (only partially readable)
- Introducing bad items (which do not correspond to a label)

Details: The robot repackages bulk electronic components from their shipping trays into packages of the correct quantity to fulfill customer orders. The type of package (bag/partial tray) varies depending on the amount of items left in the bulk tray and the size of the order
Notes: - A complex reasoning task which requires the robot to understand numbers and reason through efficient use of parts
Variations:
- The type of component (and number of components per tray)
- The order size
- The sequence of orders (which changes the part allocation)

Details: The robot builds various structures from toy wooden blocks without knocking the structures over
Notes: - A toy task which requires high levels of dexterity
Variations:
- The strucuture being built
- The trace aborts when the structure falls, and the successful portions is collected for training
